results.title: Neighbours (the remix) - Brook Andrew (Hail Amerika)
results.brief_description: The new work for Neighbours (the remix) is obvious in nature. It repeats American logo. In Australia, I find my life pervaded by Amerikanism. My art practice comments on Amerikanisation within Australian and the world culture and mediums, so with all the current world domination attitudes by Amerika, it pops up again. This time like a resounding hammer bashing down hard on the little people who have no power but to listen and bob heads, ‘yes…I do’. Fear is translated through our determination to buy McDonalds and waver in American soapies, news and perspectives.

results.title: Spin the bottle
results.brief_description: This Stylised documentary film material follows a group of teenagers at a party that gradually disintegrates over the course of a night. An inspiring miniature, it traces the rhythms of an adolescent gathering with a sense of poetry, intimacy and remarkable simplicity.

results.title: Slow Service
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour, silent
results.brief_description:
‘Slow Service’ is a series of portraits shot using a high speed video camera. This camera, which is normally used for filming mine detonations, science experiments and military tests, captures 1000 frames a second. The footage, when played back at 25 frames per second, has been slowed down so that a second of real time takes forty seconds on the screen. ‘I asked the subjects to pose as if for a passport photograph. We see the transition between this artificial pose and their natural instinctive reaction to the bucket of food that is being thrown at them, and then the impact of the food itself.

I liked the idea of capturing a wasteful, slapstick, human gesture using a medium that is normally reserved for ‘serious’ scientists and bomb designers’. (Marcus Lyall, 2004)

results.title: The Date: an interactive movie
results.brief_description: Based on the ‘choose your own adventure’ books from the 1980’s, the outcome of this interactive movie rests with the user. The shy boy central character has managed to score a date with the girl of his dreams - it is up to the user to determine whether he is successful or a miserable failure.

results.title: Consumatic
results.brief_description: A product of a final year research project from the Victoria University of Technology (VUT) Advanced Diploma of Arts (Electronic Design and Interactive Media) course. Consumatic is a dystopic view of consumerism structured around a journey through the urban environment of Melbourne.

results.title: Three Mile Creek
results.brief_description:
One of 6 works selected by AIM director David Atkinson as representing the best interactive work produced by the AIM centre up until 2004. Three Mile Creek is a collection of anecdotal accounts inspired by an experience of growing up in rural northern NSW. The aim is to transport the participant into what is a distinctively Australian time and place, with the child who lives on the farm as their guide.
A contemplative approach is the key to appreciating the stories. Music, dialogue and soundscape evoke the richness of the environment and create the sense of being there

results.title: Warrior women
results.creator_credit: Jacqui Ward, Michael Buckley, Sue Smith, Generation Films and Christine Gillespie
results.brief_description:
The Warrior Women CDROM and booklet evolved out of the Warrior Women Exhibiiton. Warrior Women is a moving, insightful and innovative mixed media art exhibiiton created by women exploring their experiences of breast cancer. Women of all ages, cultural and social backgrounds collaborated with women artists to develop this significant exhibition. The collaborations took place over a two year period and resulted in over 100 pieces of art including videos, projections, audio, slides, photographs, digital designs and writing.

The Australia Council for the Arts funded the redevelopment of the Warrior Women Exhibition artworks into a booklet and an interactive CDROM. These were distributed throughout Australia by the Breast Cancer Network, Australia.

results.title: Constructing cyburbia
results.creator_credit: Emma Byrnes and Victoria University Press
results.brief_description: A CD-ROM constructed as part of an interactive media course at Victoria University of Technology, Constructing Cyburbia is a documentary-style look at the linked sociological phenomena of home renovation and personal homepage development. The work uses interviews and examples to affectionately explore common elements and aesthetic styles of the personal homepage.

results.title: Shocked
results.creator_credit: Danielle Karalus and Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television
results.brief_description: Shocked takes takes you on a psychological journey with Jessica and you are asked to determine her future. Jessica’s perfect perfect world crumbles after the birth of her first child. The increasing pace and often chaotic nature of the interface and soundscape matches the chaotic world that Jessica inhabits. Shocked; game-like in its interactivity, is so real it makes you question your own values, and is so compelling you won’t be able to stop.

creators_primary.name: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television

results.title: Wedding
results.brief_description:
An interactive CD-ROM produced as part of Victorian College of the Arts Interactive Media degree. ‘Wedding’ allows an interactive exploration of different characters at a wedding. A wide range of permuations are generated as the user selects characters to interact with each other; triggering recorded conversations and short movie pieces.

“Wedding explores behaviours and expectations that seem to be exclusively associated with weddings. Not only from the bride, but from her friends and family as well - it seemed that weddings stil retain much of their symbolic power in people’s imagination. ‘Wedding’ uses interactivity to give the user the chance to explore a non-linear situationwith characters that they choose and identify with or are interested in”.
